<p><strong>The European freight rail</strong> industry has seen a steady decline over the past 70 years. Freight rails modal share has decreased from around 60 percent in the 1950s, and 30 percent in the 1980s, to roughly 15 percent today, driven mainly by large industry shifts.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="72ed9395-f750-4e97-8d8c-74db694c4c8e"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="72ed9395-f750-4e97-8d8c-74db694c4c8e" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Jose Vassallo and Mark Fagan, <em>Nature or nurture: Why do railroads carry greater freight share in the United States than in Europe?</em>, Taubman Center research working paper series, number WP05-15, December 20, 2005; European Commission, Eurostat Freight transport statistics  modal split; Deutsches Institut fr Wirtschaftsforschung (DIW), Verkehr in Zahlen, Hamburg: Bundesministerium fr Verkehr (Federal Ministry of Transport), 2000 and 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> This prompted a vicious circle of increasing fixed costs, leading to loss of competitiveness and loss of volume, and consequently increasing fixed costs againwith little hope for a thriving future. The rise of new small and agile entrants worsened the situation for freight rail incumbents that were left with unhealthy structures and often faced political pressure to maintain unprofitable businesses.</p>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the authors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>This article is a collaborative effort by Raphalle Chapuis, Theo Delporte, Steffen Kpke, <a href="/sitecore/service/notfound.aspx?item=web%3a%7bc84a662a-7428-4aea-a302-1c479714b5af%7d%40en">Carsten Lotz</a>, and Anselm Ott.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>The European Union has set a bold ambition to reverse this trend. It plans to double freight rails modal share by 2030, both to reduce the transport sectors CO2 emissions and to ease the congestion of major road connections.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a9ab4d2b-1104-47ac-81de-d48b51de8d76"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">2</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a9ab4d2b-1104-47ac-81de-d48b51de8d76" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">30 by 2030: <em>Rail freight strategy to boost modal shift</em>, Rail Freight Forward; European Commission, Mobility Strategy.</span></span></span></a></span> Achieving this ambition would see freight rail volumes grow by around six percent a year in ton-kilometers (tkm).</p>

<p>A massive shift in trajectory would be required to achieve this ambition. A European strategy to transfer a large proportion of transport from road to rail could focus on several key elements, including major long-distance freight flows, key connection points such as ports, and new industries that can replace volumes lost in declining sectors. Regulators and operators could also play a role in rethinking the regulatory model and reorienting the industry to become more customer focused, and more profitable.</p>

<h2>Doubling freight rails modal share requires major transformation</h2>

<!-- -->

<p>As far back as 2011, the European Commission set a target of shifting as much as 30 percent of road freight that is transported further than 300km to other modes of transport, such as rail or waterborne transport by 2030and to increase this to more than 50 percent by 2050.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="dbb65998-3c34-4ca6-9503-d2645a08d780"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">3</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="dbb65998-3c34-4ca6-9503-d2645a08d780" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Rail freight transport in the EU: Still not on the right track</em>, European Court of Auditors, 2016.</span></span></span></a></span> Such targets have been confirmed recently on the European level<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9789f532-f456-4465-ac4c-8a7a0b5ddee9"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">4</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9789f532-f456-4465-ac4c-8a7a0b5ddee9" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">30 by 2030: <em>Rail freight strategy to boost modal shift</em>, Rail Freight Forward; European Commission, Mobility Strategy.</span></span></span></a></span> and also by member states, such as France and Spain.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6ada4082-afe1-42c8-9692-910baa942e8b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">5</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6ada4082-afe1-42c8-9692-910baa942e8b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">David Burroughs, Spain outlines 1.5bn investment to improve intermodal freight, International Railway Journal, June 3, 2021; French Rail Freight of the Future (4F) website.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>These objectives are in line with the motivation to build a greener and more digital transportation system that will be more resilient to future crises, particularly in the context of the Paris Agreement on climate and the stimulus plan launched to deal with the economic crisis associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the effort required to double freight rails modal share throughout the EU will be substantial. Goods transported by rail would increase from 420 billion tkm today to approximately 1,000 billion tkm in 2030a yearly growth of 6.1 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1a837577-3414-4a71-bae3-0c2ecd659e32"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">6</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1a837577-3414-4a71-bae3-0c2ecd659e32" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eurostat, Goods transported dataset, 2003-2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>What this means in practice is that France and Germany, for example, would need to shift 90 percent of goods that are transported more than 500kmand 50 percent of goods transported more than 300kmto rail to boost todays modal share from 19 percent and 10 percent respectively to the target of 30 percent. Similarly, for Spain to boost modal share from 5 percent today to 30 percent, it would need to shift 55 percent of transports beyond 500km, or 40 percent of transports beyond 300km to rail.</p>

<p>In an alternative perspective, reaching 30 percent modal share would mean shifting 70 percent of food and agricultural products from road to rail in Spain. Meanwhile in Germany, the 30 percent goal could be reached by shifting 60 percent of all metal and ore volumes to rail.</p>

<p>Given todays preference for truck transport, the freight rail industry will need to undergo a major performance shift if it is to provide a competitive alternative. Today, truck transport is better positioned than rail in terms of cost, flexibility, and reach.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="9166a8eb-46e6-4160-b2ce-987b08558823"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">7</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="9166a8eb-46e6-4160-b2ce-987b08558823" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Freight on Road: Why Shippers prefer truck to train</em>, Directorate General for Internal Policies, European Parliament, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span> Furthermore, truck transport is expected to gain a cost advantage of between 20 and 30 percent by 2050, given advances in driverless operations, flow optimization by advanced analytics, and fuel efficiency. The rail industry would need to at least match these cost savings, if not exceed them significantly, to gain market share.</p>

<p>The situation is intensified by the fact that traditional customer industries for freight railsuch as coal, iron ore, and petrolare declining. In fact, they are expected to decrease by 1 percent a year until 2030.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="de171225-7cd1-4daa-a750-640fbbdf2983"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">9</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="de171225-7cd1-4daa-a750-640fbbdf2983" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Comparative Industry Service, IHS Markit.</span></span></span></a></span> To make up for lost volumes, rail will need to grow seven times faster than road transport to reach the expected modal share of 30 percent.</p>

<h2>Freight rail in Western Europe has seen a steady decline</h2>

<p>Freight rails modal share has been in decline across Europe, both in terms of market share and the profitability of major operators. In France for instance, modal share declined by 50 percent, from around 30 percent in the 1980s to 15 percent today. By contrast, road transport has been steadily increasing. In 1980, less than 50 percent of goods were transported by road. This rose to more than 75 percent by 2018.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="b5b7a2eb-e92d-4bf6-ac24-8d251c61e04b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">10</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="b5b7a2eb-e92d-4bf6-ac24-8d251c61e04b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Les comptes des transports 2019</em>, French government Data and Statistical Studies Service (SDES), 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The decline in freight rail can be attributed to three factors: a loss or decline of key customer industries, the withdrawal of railways from providing various unprofitable services, and road transport improving its relative cost position compared to rail services.</p>

<p>First, traditional heavy-industry clients disappeared, particularly coal and steel. For instance, European coal production decreased by 60 percent between 1990 and 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="4f7de25a-270d-4641-887b-8674a65d5176"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">11</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="4f7de25a-270d-4641-887b-8674a65d5176" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">World total coal production,1971-2020, International Energy Agency (IEA), 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> In the United Kingdom, the phasing out of coal in the power industry caused a drop of 85 percent of the tkm performance of coal transport by rail.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="1fabc078-bce3-476e-8b53-c04301c757ab"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">12</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="1fabc078-bce3-476e-8b53-c04301c757ab" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">In the UK, rail freights modal share dropped from 23 percent in 2013 to 17 percent in 2016, UK Department of Transports statistical dataset for freight (TSGB04).</span></span></span></a></span> And in Germany, the volume of coal, iron, and metal transported dropped by around 85 million tons between 1970 and 2017representing a 60 percent drop in the volume of freight rail from all sectors in the country.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ffa21ce9-349d-440b-a621-cfd9f86311f4"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">13</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ffa21ce9-349d-440b-a621-cfd9f86311f4" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Federal Statistical Office of Germany (Destatis); Deutsches Institut fr Wirtschaftsforschung (DIW<em>), Verkehr in Zahlen</em>, Hamburg: Bundesministerium fr Verkehr (Federal Ministry of Transport), 2000 and 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Second, railways discontinued or reduced certain servicessuch as single wagonload, break bulk transport, and expedited overnight servicesas these showed low or negative margins and faced heavy competition from road transport. Countries like Spain, the United Kingdom, and Denmark, for instance, no longer see any single wagonload traffic, which used to comprise 20 to 40 percent of all rail transport. In parallel, associated infrastructure was heavily reduced. For example, in Germany over the last 25 years the number of private rail sidings dropped from around 11,500 to around 2,300.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="bfc60bae-107e-4865-9ad2-1f70c58899ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">14</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="bfc60bae-107e-4865-9ad2-1f70c58899ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Sidings in the German rail network (Gleisanschlsse im deutschen Bahnnetz)</em>, Deutscher Bundestag (Drs. 19/9305).</span></span></span></a></span> Similarly, in France the number of private access points dropped from roughly 11,200 in 1970 to 1,150 in 2019.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="0e3eefb6-4af4-4f65-9a89-ce1f43ff9286"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">15</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="0e3eefb6-4af4-4f65-9a89-ce1f43ff9286" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Quel fret ferroviaire local ? Ralits franaises, clairages allemands. La documentation franaise, 2009 ; NPI ; Cerema 2019.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>Third, road transport saw a significant improvement in productivity with the arrival of more fuel-efficient trucks. Companies were also able to engage workers at lower wage levels, for instance by hiring drivers from Eastern Europe. Additionally, new transport demands such as the need for greater flexibility to accommodate just-in-time production, smaller lot sizes, and decentralized flows gave road freight a natural advantage.</p>

<p>The loss of rail volumes and a decline in competitiveness, in combination with a market opening up to private road players, initiated a vicious cycle: declining volumeat high fixed costled to the cutting of non-profitable services resulting in a high fixed-cost structure not sufficiently covered by revenue growth. In a low margin industry, this situation involves structural losses that are hard to recover, especially in an economic crisis.</p>

<h2>Exceptions and successes exist</h2>

<p>While freight rail modal share declined across Europe, some countries and operators have managed to stabilize modal shareor even slightly grow it. Examples of successes highlight some key lessons which others can follow.</p>

<p>Germany, for instance, increased rails modal share from 16 to 19 percent over the last twenty years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="797f8aac-6f9b-483b-97a8-7409d4b788c7"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">16</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="797f8aac-6f9b-483b-97a8-7409d4b788c7" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Federal Statistical Office of Germany (Destatis).</span></span></span></a></span> This was driven mainly by a significant growth in exports and the use of container transport from the countrys ports to industrial centers in the mainland. However, this required a targeted push to boost modal share by investing heavily in rail infrastructure at key connection points over the last 25 years. For example, investments in the Port of Hamburg led to an increase in its rail share of hinterland container traffic from around 30 to just over 50 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="562ca50d-26e0-4280-adcd-996223eac225"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">17</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="562ca50d-26e0-4280-adcd-996223eac225" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Port of Hamburg, Modal split in hinterland traffic 2020; <em>Entwicklungen im Containerverkehr in Hamburg und der Nordrange</em>, Port of Hamburg, 2005.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In the United Kingdom, rail volume dropped by 28 percent, from 18 billion tkm in 1980 to 13 billion tkm in 1995, reflecting the loss of British hard coal and steel customers. But between 1995 and 2015 rail freight volume grew 46 percent to 22 billion tkm, because privatized players were able to attract new customer segments, particularly the construction industry, as well as service intermodal flows to and from ports.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="760e6016-b7dd-41d5-83b6-7219b883778c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">18</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="760e6016-b7dd-41d5-83b6-7219b883778c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Nikolaos Zahariadis, Markets, States and Public Policy  Privatization in Britain and France</em>, University of Michigan, 1995; UK Department of Transports statistical dataset for freight, (TSGB04).</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In Belgium and Poland, cargo units underwent privatization and were able to reorient their business models, thereby growing volumes while significantly cutting costs.</p>

<p>Austria has managed, over roughly 30 years, to keep its freight rail modal share just above 30 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c5426216-2c8a-4a5e-99c1-f17ef1df65ad"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">19</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c5426216-2c8a-4a5e-99c1-f17ef1df65ad" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Statistik Austria, Bundesanstalt Statistik sterreich, 2021.</span></span></span></a></span> This was achieved through direct and indirect support for the industry. Such support includes subsidies for operations and investments; a differentiated tonnage limit for road transport that decreases the attractiveness of road transport for international freight transit; substantial tolls on highways; and weekend and overnight traffic bans for international transit.</p>

<p>Switzerland has followed a similarly rigorous approach, while also massively investing in rail infrastructure. For example, the new Gotthard Tunnel allows for longer and heavier trains thereby reducing costs. Swiss Railways expects this intervention to increase freight rail volumes between Switzerland and Italy by 20 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="7c8953c5-d400-445f-8999-72c9942851cb"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">20</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="7c8953c5-d400-445f-8999-72c9942851cb" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Schneller nach Italien  Gotthard-Basistunnel</em>, Eurotransport, 2015.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>In addition to these European outliers, examples from the United States show that an industry consolidation can also have positive effects. The United States had 41 Class I railroad companies in 1978 but the market had consolidated to seven major players by 2020.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="6c426be5-7626-4fba-9dda-95b189cdee04"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">21</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="6c426be5-7626-4fba-9dda-95b189cdee04" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The United States Surface Transportation Board, 2020.</span></span></span></a></span> This improved railway companies efficiency as well as profitability. They are now in a better position to innovate, have a more consistent pricing approach, and yield higher operating synergies, for example through better asset utilization. Furthermore, automated couplingplanned in Europe since around the 1970s and expected to be implemented from 2025 onwards has been a US market standard for more than 100 years.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="c7a780aa-6fb0-4b69-8cb1-513fbea72f8c"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">22</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="c7a780aa-6fb0-4b69-8cb1-513fbea72f8c" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Development of a concept for the EU-wide migration to a Digital Automatic Coupling System (DAC) for Rail Freight Transportation, German Ministry of Transport and Digital Infrastructure (BMVI), June 2020.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p>The following three key lessons emerge from these success stories.</p>

<p>First, <em>railways could benefit from new dedicated target segments, convincing business plans, and concrete actions to increase modal share</em>. The industry needs to be cognizant of the fact that traffic will not shift gradually, and old volumes are gone. On a country level, Austria and Switzerland provide good examples of concrete plans to shift freight from road to rail. The British and Belgian success stories illustrate the kind of management excellence needed at a company level to move forward.</p>

<p>Second, <em>targeted infrastructure investment is key</em>. For instance, the Gotthard Tunnel and investment in the Port of Hamburg have each triggered a massive shift. By comparison, investments dispersed across European networks may have improved the situation, but have not been able to move the needle on modal share.</p>

<p>Third, <em>the industry requires bold regulatory moves</em>. Switzerland and Austria, for example, have implemented a series of effective measures, which went beyond subsidizing rail on an incremental level.</p>

<h2>A European rail freight transformation can focus on three key elements</h2>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The following strategic interventions could help to win traffic back for rail</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><ul>
    <li><em>Enabling seamless movement across borders.</em> There is a standard gauge connection to Barcelona, and beyond, through a new high-speed line; similar capacity could be added at border crossings such as Port Bou and Cerbere.</li>
    <li><em>Increasing corridor capacity.</em> Connecting corridors, especially along the Mediterranean coast in France and Spain, need increased capacity to handle larger flows. Part of the solution could include adding European Train Control System (ETCS) equipment and removing level crossings.</li>
    <li><em>Giving customers access points.</em> Standard gauge connections in Spain could be expanded so that key areas of origin, such as Almeria, have direct access to the standard gauge network. In addition, infrastructure investments need to incorporate high-capacity terminals which can handle 740m trains efficiently.</li>
    <li><em>Offering attractive supply-chain solutions.</em> Appropriate supply-chain solutionswith clear benefits over road transport in terms of cost, reliability, and speedcould attract key industries. For instance, as a significant portion of traffic is made up of perishable agricultural products, rail will need to compete with door-to-door truck services that provide fresh food to customers. Solutions could include cold-chain services based on reefer containers, average train speeds of more than 80km per hour between terminals, and reliable schedules.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>A concrete transformation to successfully boost freight rail in Europe could focus on the following three elements: major transportation flows such as those between Spain and Central and Northern Europe; major connection points such as ports that handle a large proportion of the import and export flows; and new industries that could shift to rail and replace the volume lost by industries such as coal and steel.</p>

<h3>West-East cross-border transportation flows</h3>

<p>Huge volumes of goods are transported across the continent, but the majority move by road. There is an opportunity to focus on the largest flows and put interventions in place to shift these volumes to freight rail. Major flows move from Spain and Portugal, across France to countries in Central and Northern Europe, particularly Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands. More than 40 billion tkm of road freight move across France per year, with an average transport distance of over 500kmthis distance is the sweet spot for rail transport, yet only 5 percent is on rail.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ac1b994a-c29f-455a-9be9-914f4116492b"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">23</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ac1b994a-c29f-455a-9be9-914f4116492b" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Eurostat, Annual road freight transport, by distance class.</span></span></span></a></span> Capturing 50 percent of this traffic would boost freight rail modal share in France by 5.5 percentage points, from 8.7 percent to 14.2 percent.</p>

<p>With dedicated investment and new business models, rail has a potential to win back a significant share of traffic, especially given consumer demand for supply chains which are more sustainable in terms of carbon footprint.</p>

<h3>Ports on Europes North-South axis</h3>

<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__share-icons-wrapper__9gB_c"><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-outer__UdWCq"><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__eyebrow__5GSEq">Sidebar</div><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content__raEwe"><h2 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>The Port of Hamburgs success factors</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p>Four success factors seem to have helped the port to make rail attractive and increase modal share:</p>

<p><em>Opening up access to rail infrastructure.</em> Opening tracks within the port to all railway operators increased shippers willingness to move goods on rail as they could tailor their solutions with preferred partners. Service qualityfor example, the frequency of train servicesincreased significantly. There are now 57 different rail transport companies using the ports infrastructure, with 1,300 trains per week going in and out of the port.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="a1adfc02-6ca8-4932-8588-a0e817655dbe"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="a1adfc02-6ca8-4932-8588-a0e817655dbe" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Hamburg Port Railways</em>, Hamburg Port Authority.</span></span></span></a></span></p>

<p><em>Reducing infrastructure bottlenecks.</em> The port improved both infrastructure and operations to speed up and increase capacity on rail services. It removed infrastructural bottlenecks, for instance by completing the Kattwyk railway bridge in 2020. This is one of the largest lifting bridges in the world, with a middle section that can be raised to allow ships to pass underneath. Dedicated to rail traffic, the bridge has increased capacity for rail services.</p>

<p><em>Cooperating closely in operations.</em> The Hamburg port provides shunting services as well as joint traffic management with other companies, leading to increased operational efficiency.</p>

<p><em>Connecting the hinterland.</em> Building rail infrastructure in the rest of the country was just as important as increasing infrastructure at the port, so the system could handle larger numbers of trains. Segments with third tracks and sidings have been added to handle 740m trainsand new freight arteries are planned for the future.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>

<p>Ports play a major role in the transport of European goods, handling around 50 percent of imports and exports. Rail access to ports is therefore a crucial factor in fulfilling Europes aspiration for freight rail. A good example is the Port of Hamburg. The ports long-term strategy of hinterland connectivity has always been a core pillar of its activities, enabling the port to increase its rail modal share to 51 percent (see sidebar, The Port of Hamburgs success factors).</p>

<p>Other European ports could launch similar initiatives and upgrade infrastructure, as a core priority for increasing rail flows. Several of the major European import and export port hubs have very low rail modal share, for example, 17 percent in Felixstowe, 8 percent in Antwerp, and 7 percent in Valencia. Boosting those modal shares to the region of 40 to 50 percent would have significant impact on the overall modal share of rail freight in Europe.</p>

<h3>New customer industries</h3>

<p>There is an opportunity to attract new customers to rail, particularly by expanding market share in the paper and pulp, and battery industries. Today, around 300 million tons of wood are produced in the EU, and most of this is transported by truck over short distances to factories and production sites. According to our analyses, at least 20 percent is transported over longer distances, of 250 to 400 km, for which rail would be more suitable. Capturing these flows could potentially add 14 to 15 billion tkm to rails modal share.</p>

<p>Another possibility could be to capture new European customers that produce batteries for electric vehicles. An average battery has a weight of around 300 to 500 kg for a mid-sized car. Given current production levels of around 20 million cars per yearand the fact that production of combustion engines will likely cease by 2040this industry has the potential to add demand for around 5 billion tkm of freight rail per year.</p>

<p>Both wood and batteries are suitable for rail and are often located in specific regions. Putting these industries logistics and supply chains on rail would require some targeted investments, including the establishment of sidings or direct access points to the rail network; measures to fully optimize last-mile management; and a high level of service to bring both reliability and flexibility to cater to clients needs.</p>

<h2>Rethinking the regulation model</h2>

<p>To support these big moves, regulators, alongside infrastructure managers and owners, could consider various actions on the following dimensions to support freight railbeyond short-term subsidiesand set the foundation for a financially viable sector:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>Integrate rail and road infrastructure charges.</em> Stakeholders could develop an integrated view and financing approach, across rail and road, that reflects similar costs. Today, significant costs of transport are externalized and born by society at large. However, road transport is responsible for a greater share of these costs. A 2012 report from the International Union of Railways (UIC) states that heavy duty vehicles are responsible for 14 percent of all external costs of transport in Europe, and light duty vehicles are responsible for 9 percent.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="3ce81b0d-a9bc-40bf-b5d4-89f34bd6173f"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">24</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="3ce81b0d-a9bc-40bf-b5d4-89f34bd6173f" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline"><em>Greening transport: Reducing external costs</em>, International Union of Railways (UIC), June 1, 2012.</span></span></span></a></span> This figure is only 1 percent for rail. Establishing a level playing field would help companies choose the best transport mode, including being able to take sustainability issues into consideration.</li>
<li><em>Dedicate tracks to freight rail.</em> In Europe, passenger rail is prioritized over freight rail. Access to daytime slots, especially close to critical nodes such as Paris or Lyon in France, is almost impossible for freight trains. As the EU has a comparable ambition to grow passenger rail, this raises the question of additional rail capacity or even dedicated lines for freight. A European freight rail master planincluding dedicated projects, funding, and governancecould prioritize end-to-end projects across Europe.</li>
<li><em>Consider infrastructure as a public good.</em> The question of whether a road connecting two small villages is worth building is almost never asked; however, for more than 30 years, rail infrastructure operators have prioritized profitable lines over unprofitable ones based on the tolls they could generate. An alternative approach could be to determine the value of a specific line in the context of its ecosystem, including the industries, territories, and main lines it serves.</li>
<li><em>Enable new technology.</em> The technology to enable next-generation freight exists and has been on the market for several years, including track and trace, ERTMS, automatic coupling, and automated terminals. However, this is still being tested. For example, DB in Germany and SNCF in France are testing several automated coupling technologiesno standards have been chosen yet, and rollout is not expected for several years. Accelerating this process is key.</li>
<li><em>Revisit the European competitive framework.</em> The current operating model, including a privatized and liberalized market, leads to competition on marginal cost in an industry that already has a high fixed-cost share. The market has separated into various segments. There is a focus on highly competitive and profitable segmentssuch as long complete trains, and long distancesand on segments that can only be made profitable as a feeder for other transport, such as single wagon loads or short distances. Regional traffic, which incurs major losses, is thus usually only offered by big incumbents.</li>
</ul>

<h2>Operators could focus on customer orientation</h2>

<p>Operators could play a role in reshaping the market. They could consider taking a more strategic approach to reorienting services to better meet customer needs. Over the last 10 to 20 years, operators have been focused on operational turnarounds. Changes in ownership have been driven mainly by the need to inject fresh capital or by the will to get rid of costly legacies and to run a more profit-oriented model. Examples include the Lineas private equity carve-out, IPO in Poland, Dutch Rail being taken over by DB Cargo, the majority interest of CFL Luxembourg and of Comboios de Portugal being sold to major customers, and Swiss Cargo opening up ownership to private investors.</p>

<p>However, in comparable cases in other industriessuch as express logistics, freight forwarding, telecommunications, airlines, and energythere has been a rise in trans-national companies with an international footprint that outweighs their incumbent markets by far. This phenomenon is often driven by large cross-border M&A activity. Successful companies in these industries have significantly revisited their commercial models, improved customer experience across process steps, introduced flexible offerings, enhanced quality of service, and offered better pricing structures. Freight rail would also benefit from thinking through its marketing and customer relationship models, which have not seen significant changes over the past 50 years. In this context, rail operators could explore four options for developing new market share:</p>

<ul>
<li><em>Improve cost efficiencies</em> by using all possibilities to improve economies of scale, scope, and skills. For example, rail operators could create truly seamless networks across the EU; develop new operating models to cover the first and last mile; consider partnerships with other rail operators or new actors; and leverage new technologies such as automatic coupling to optimize operations, automatic processing to simplify back-office processes, and advanced analytics to optimize network planning and train scheduling.</li>
<li><em>Offer world-class service</em> by applying the latest technologies to enhance processes from customer generation through to pricing and after sales service. For example, rail operators could implement easy web-based booking solutions for end-to-end logistics across operators and infrastructure managers; apply advanced pricing approaches to attract volume; and optimize margins.</li>
<li><em>Develop competitive insights</em> by understanding the competitions value add for clients and their pricing approach. For example, rail operators could develop a clean sheeting tool for competitive modes, develop new tools to predict needs, and design select pricing points to offer a better value proposition to clients.</li>
<li><em>Proactively look for new clients</em> by developing new offerings to attract new types of goods to rail; and potentially developing partnership with companies willing to lower their carbon emissions and create a more sustainable operation strategy.</li>
</ul>

<hr>

<p>Doubling freight rails modal share represents a significant challenge. It requires real will, strong choices, and an active involvement of all stakeholders, including states, regulators, operators, infrastructure managers, and industries.</p>

<p>Investing in technology, and modernizing the network, will be criticalbut this is only part of what is needed to truly transform the industry. Regulators could also provide support, particularly in revising the competitive and financial model. And operators would benefit from rethinking their business models and coming up with innovative ways to attract new clients and deliver value.</p></div><div Card_content-block__pF6Z1"><span>Article</span><h6 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-6"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Bold moves to boost European rail freight","displayName":"Bold moves to boost European rail freight","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"cd638bef-5298-448c-a31f-a63a3f72937b","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Bold moves to boost European rail freight"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"European rail freight transformation"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Europe\u0026rsquo;s big aspiration to reverse the decline of its rail freight industry will require significant effort, with substantial investment and smart thinking. Governments and industry players can help to achieve this goal, as there are examples of success to draw on and some key levers to pull."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"How to increase the modal share of freight rail in Europe?"},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-01-21T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThe European freight rail\u003c/strong\u003e industry has seen a steady decline over the past 70 years. Freight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share has decreased from around 60 percent in the 1950s, and 30 percent in the 1980s, to roughly 15 percent today, driven mainly by large industry shifts.[[footnote 1]] This prompted a vicious circle of increasing fixed costs, leading to loss of competitiveness and loss of volume, and consequently increasing fixed costs again\u0026mdash;with little hope for a thriving future. The rise of new small and agile entrants worsened the situation for freight rail incumbents that were left with unhealthy structures and often faced political pressure to maintain unprofitable businesses.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n[[sidebar authors]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe European Union has set a bold ambition to reverse this trend. It plans to double freight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share by 2030, both to reduce the transport sector\u0026rsquo;s CO2 emissions and to ease the congestion of major road connections.[[footnote 2]] Achieving this ambition would see freight rail volumes grow by around six percent a year in ton-kilometers (tkm).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eA massive shift in trajectory would be required to achieve this ambition. A European strategy to transfer a large proportion of transport from road to rail could focus on several key elements, including major long-distance freight flows, key connection points such as ports, and new industries that can replace volumes lost in declining sectors. Regulators and operators could also play a role in rethinking the regulatory model and reorienting the industry to become more customer focused, and more profitable.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eDoubling freight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share requires major transformation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eAs far back as 2011, the European Commission set a target of shifting as much as 30 percent of road freight that is transported further than 300km to other modes of transport, such as rail or waterborne transport by 2030\u0026mdash;and to increase this to more than 50 percent by 2050.[[footnote 3]] Such targets have been confirmed recently on the European level[[footnote 4]] and also by member states, such as France and Spain.[[footnote 5]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThese objectives are in line with the motivation to build a greener and more digital transportation system that will be more resilient to future crises, particularly in the context of the Paris Agreement on climate and the stimulus plan launched to deal with the economic crisis associated with the COVID-19 pandemic. However, the effort required to double freight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share throughout the EU will be substantial. Goods transported by rail would increase from 420 billion tkm today to approximately 1,000 billion tkm in 2030\u0026mdash;a yearly growth of 6.1 percent.[[footnote 6]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhat this means in practice is that France and Germany, for example, would need to shift 90 percent of goods that are transported more than 500km\u0026mdash;and 50 percent of goods transported more than 300km\u0026mdash;to rail to boost today\u0026rsquo;s modal share from 19 percent and 10 percent respectively to the target of 30 percent. Similarly, for Spain to boost modal share from 5 percent today to 30 percent, it would need to shift 55 percent of transports beyond 500km, or 40 percent of transports beyond 300km to rail.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn an alternative perspective, reaching 30 percent modal share would mean shifting 70 percent of food and agricultural products from road to rail in Spain. Meanwhile in Germany, the 30 percent goal could be reached by shifting 60 percent of all metal and ore volumes to rail.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eGiven today\u0026rsquo;s preference for truck transport, the freight rail industry will need to undergo a major performance shift if it is to provide a competitive alternative. Today, truck transport is better positioned than rail in terms of cost, flexibility, and reach.[[footnote 7]] Furthermore, truck transport is expected to gain a cost advantage of between 20 and 30 percent by 2050, given advances in driverless operations, flow optimization by advanced analytics, and fuel efficiency. The rail industry would need to at least match these cost savings, if not exceed them significantly, to gain market share.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe situation is intensified by the fact that traditional customer industries for freight rail\u0026mdash;such as coal, iron ore, and petrol\u0026mdash;are declining. In fact, they are expected to decrease by 1 percent a year until 2030.[[footnote 9]] To make up for lost volumes, rail will need to grow seven times faster than road transport to reach the expected modal share of 30 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eFreight rail in Western Europe has seen a steady decline\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFreight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share has been in decline across Europe, both in terms of market share and the profitability of major operators. In France for instance, modal share declined by 50 percent, from around 30 percent in the 1980s to 15 percent today. By contrast, road transport has been steadily increasing. In 1980, less than 50 percent of goods were transported by road. This rose to more than 75 percent by 2018.[[footnote 10]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe decline in freight rail can be attributed to three factors: a loss or decline of key customer industries, the withdrawal of railways from providing various unprofitable services, and road transport improving its relative cost position compared to rail services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, traditional heavy-industry clients disappeared, particularly coal and steel. For instance, European coal production decreased by 60 percent between 1990 and 2019.[[footnote 11]] In the United Kingdom, the phasing out of coal in the power industry caused a drop of 85 percent of the tkm performance of coal transport by rail.[[footnote 12]] And in Germany, the volume of coal, iron, and metal transported dropped by around 85 million tons between 1970 and 2017\u0026mdash;representing a 60 percent drop in the volume of freight rail from all sectors in the country.[[footnote 13]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, railways discontinued or reduced certain services\u0026mdash;such as single wagonload, break bulk transport, and expedited overnight services\u0026mdash;as these showed low or negative margins and faced heavy competition from road transport. Countries like Spain, the United Kingdom, and Denmark, for instance, no longer see any single wagonload traffic, which used to comprise 20 to 40 percent of all rail transport. In parallel, associated infrastructure was heavily reduced. For example, in Germany over the last 25 years the number of private rail sidings dropped from around 11,500 to around 2,300.[[footnote 14]] Similarly, in France the number of private access points dropped from roughly 11,200 in 1970 to 1,150 in 2019.[[footnote 15]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThird, road transport saw a significant improvement in productivity with the arrival of more fuel-efficient trucks. Companies were also able to engage workers at lower wage levels, for instance by hiring drivers from Eastern Europe. Additionally, new transport demands such as the need for greater flexibility to accommodate just-in-time production, smaller lot sizes, and decentralized flows gave road freight a natural advantage.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe loss of rail volumes and a decline in competitiveness, in combination with a market opening up to private road players, initiated a vicious cycle: declining volume\u0026mdash;at high fixed cost\u0026mdash;led to the cutting of non-profitable services resulting in a high fixed-cost structure not sufficiently covered by revenue growth. In a low margin industry, this situation involves structural losses that are hard to recover, especially in an economic crisis.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eExceptions and successes exist\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWhile freight rail modal share declined across Europe, some countries and operators have managed to stabilize modal share\u0026mdash;or even slightly grow it. Examples of successes highlight some key lessons which others can follow.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eGermany, for instance, increased rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share from 16 to 19 percent over the last twenty years.[[footnote 16]] This was driven mainly by a significant growth in exports and the use of container transport from the country\u0026rsquo;s ports to industrial centers in the mainland. However, this required a targeted push to boost modal share by investing heavily in rail infrastructure at key connection points over the last 25 years. For example, investments in the Port of Hamburg led to an increase in its rail share of hinterland container traffic from around 30 to just over 50 percent.[[footnote 17]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn the United Kingdom, rail volume dropped by 28 percent, from 18 billion tkm in 1980 to 13 billion tkm in 1995, reflecting the loss of British hard coal and steel customers. But between 1995 and 2015 rail freight volume grew 46 percent to 22 billion tkm, because privatized players were able to attract new customer segments, particularly the construction industry, as well as service intermodal flows to and from ports.[[footnote 18]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn Belgium and Poland, cargo units underwent privatization and were able to reorient their business models, thereby growing volumes while significantly cutting costs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAustria has managed, over roughly 30 years, to keep its freight rail modal share just above 30 percent.[[footnote 19]] This was achieved through direct and indirect support for the industry. Such support includes subsidies for operations and investments; a differentiated tonnage limit for road transport that decreases the attractiveness of road transport for international freight transit; substantial tolls on highways; and weekend and overnight traffic bans for international transit.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSwitzerland has followed a similarly rigorous approach, while also massively investing in rail infrastructure. For example, the new Gotthard Tunnel allows for longer and heavier trains thereby reducing costs. Swiss Railways expects this intervention to increase freight rail volumes between Switzerland and Italy by 20 percent.[[footnote 20]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eIn addition to these European outliers, examples from the United States show that an industry consolidation can also have positive effects. The United States had 41 Class I railroad companies in 1978 but the market had consolidated to seven major players by 2020.[[footnote 21]] This improved railway companies\u0026rsquo; efficiency as well as profitability. They are now in a better position to innovate, have a more consistent pricing approach, and yield higher operating synergies, for example through better asset utilization. Furthermore, automated coupling\u0026mdash;planned in Europe since around the 1970s and expected to be implemented from 2025 onwards\u0026mdash; has been a US market standard for more than 100 years.[[footnote 22]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThe following three key lessons emerge from these success stories.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eFirst, \u003cem\u003erailways could benefit from new dedicated target segments, convincing business plans, and concrete actions to increase modal share\u003c/em\u003e. The industry needs to be cognizant of the fact that traffic will not shift gradually, and old volumes are gone. On a country level, Austria and Switzerland provide good examples of concrete plans to shift freight from road to rail. The British and Belgian success stories illustrate the kind of management excellence needed at a company level to move forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eSecond, \u003cem\u003etargeted infrastructure investment is key\u003c/em\u003e. For instance, the Gotthard Tunnel and investment in the Port of Hamburg have each triggered a massive shift. By comparison, investments dispersed across European networks may have improved the situation, but have not been able to move the needle on modal share.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThird, \u003cem\u003ethe industry requires bold regulatory moves\u003c/em\u003e. Switzerland and Austria, for example, have implemented a series of effective measures, which went beyond subsidizing rail on an incremental level.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eA European rail freight transformation can focus on three key elements\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 1]]\n\n\u003cp\u003eA concrete transformation to successfully boost freight rail in Europe could focus on the following three elements: major transportation flows such as those between Spain and Central and Northern Europe; major connection points such as ports that handle a large proportion of the import and export flows; and new industries that could shift to rail and replace the volume lost by industries such as coal and steel.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eWest-East cross-border transportation flows\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHuge volumes of goods are transported across the continent, but the majority move by road. There is an opportunity to focus on the largest flows and put interventions in place to shift these volumes to freight rail. Major flows move from Spain and Portugal, across France to countries in Central and Northern Europe, particularly Germany, Belgium, and the Netherlands. More than 40 billion tkm of road freight move across France per year, with an average transport distance of over 500km\u0026mdash;this distance is the sweet spot for rail transport, yet only 5 percent is on rail.[[footnote 23]] Capturing 50 percent of this traffic would boost freight rail modal share in France by 5.5 percentage points, from 8.7 percent to 14.2 percent.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eWith dedicated investment and new business models, rail has a potential to win back a significant share of traffic, especially given consumer demand for supply chains which are more sustainable in terms of carbon footprint.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003ePorts on Europe\u0026rsquo;s North-South axis\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n[[sidebar 2]]\n\n\u003cp\u003ePorts play a major role in the transport of European goods, handling around 50 percent of imports and exports. Rail access to ports is therefore a crucial factor in fulfilling Europe\u0026rsquo;s aspiration for freight rail. A good example is the Port of Hamburg. The port\u0026rsquo;s long-term strategy of hinterland connectivity has always been a core pillar of its activities, enabling the port to increase its rail modal share to 51 percent (see sidebar, \u0026ldquo;The Port of Hamburg\u0026rsquo;s success factors\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOther European ports could launch similar initiatives and upgrade infrastructure, as a core priority for increasing rail flows. Several of the major European import and export port hubs have very low rail modal share, for example, 17 percent in Felixstowe, 8 percent in Antwerp, and 7 percent in Valencia. Boosting those modal shares to the region of 40 to 50 percent would have significant impact on the overall modal share of rail freight in Europe.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch3\u003eNew customer industries\u003c/h3\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eThere is an opportunity to attract new customers to rail, particularly by expanding market share in the paper and pulp, and battery industries. Today, around 300 million tons of wood are produced in the EU, and most of this is transported by truck over short distances to factories and production sites. According to our analyses, at least 20 percent is transported over longer distances, of 250 to 400 km, for which rail would be more suitable. Capturing these flows could potentially add 14 to 15 billion tkm to rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eAnother possibility could be to capture new European customers that produce batteries for electric vehicles. An average battery has a weight of around 300 to 500 kg for a mid-sized car. Given current production levels of around 20 million cars per year\u0026mdash;and the fact that production of combustion engines will likely cease by 2040\u0026mdash;this industry has the potential to add demand for around 5 billion tkm of freight rail per year.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eBoth wood and batteries are suitable for rail and are often located in specific regions. Putting these industries\u0026rsquo; logistics and supply chains on rail would require some targeted investments, including the establishment of sidings or direct access points to the rail network; measures to fully optimize last-mile management; and a high level of service to bring both reliability and flexibility to cater to clients\u0026rsquo; needs.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eRethinking the regulation model\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eTo support these big moves, regulators, alongside infrastructure managers and owners, could consider various actions on the following dimensions to support freight rail\u0026mdash;beyond short-term subsidies\u0026mdash;and set the foundation for a financially viable sector:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIntegrate rail and road infrastructure charges.\u003c/em\u003e Stakeholders could develop an integrated view and financing approach, across rail and road, that reflects similar costs. Today, significant costs of transport are externalized and born by society at large. However, road transport is responsible for a greater share of these costs. A 2012 report from the International Union of Railways (UIC) states that heavy duty vehicles are responsible for 14 percent of all external costs of transport in Europe, and light duty vehicles are responsible for 9 percent.[[footnote 24]] This figure is only 1 percent for rail. Establishing a level playing field would help companies choose the best transport mode, including being able to take sustainability issues into consideration.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDedicate tracks to freight rail.\u003c/em\u003e In Europe, passenger rail is prioritized over freight rail. Access to daytime slots, especially close to critical nodes such as Paris or Lyon in France, is almost impossible for freight trains. As the EU has a comparable ambition to grow passenger rail, this raises the question of additional rail capacity or even dedicated lines for freight. A European freight rail master plan\u0026mdash;including dedicated projects, funding, and governance\u0026mdash;could prioritize end-to-end projects across Europe.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eConsider infrastructure as a public good.\u003c/em\u003e The question of whether a road connecting two small villages is worth building is almost never asked; however, for more than 30 years, rail infrastructure operators have prioritized profitable lines over unprofitable ones based on the tolls they could generate. An alternative approach could be to determine the value of a specific line in the context of its ecosystem, including the industries, territories, and main lines it serves.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnable new technology.\u003c/em\u003e The technology to enable next-generation freight exists and has been on the market for several years, including track and trace, ERTMS, automatic coupling, and automated terminals. However, this is still being tested. For example, DB in Germany and SNCF in France are testing several automated coupling technologies\u0026mdash;no standards have been chosen yet, and rollout is not expected for several years. Accelerating this process is key.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eRevisit the European competitive framework.\u003c/em\u003e The current operating model, including a privatized and liberalized market, leads to competition on marginal cost in an industry that already has a high fixed-cost share. The market has separated into various segments. There is a focus on highly competitive and profitable segments\u0026mdash;such as long complete trains, and long distances\u0026mdash;and on segments that can only be made profitable as a feeder for other transport, such as single wagon loads or short distances. Regional traffic, which incurs major losses, is thus usually only offered by big incumbents.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003ch2\u003eOperators could focus on customer orientation\u003c/h2\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eOperators could play a role in reshaping the market. They could consider taking a more strategic approach to reorienting services to better meet customer needs. Over the last 10 to 20 years, operators have been focused on operational turnarounds. Changes in ownership have been driven mainly by the need to inject fresh capital or by the will to get rid of costly legacies and to run a more profit-oriented model. Examples include the Lineas private equity carve-out, IPO in Poland, Dutch Rail being taken over by DB Cargo, the majority interest of CFL Luxembourg and of Comboios de Portugal being sold to major customers, and Swiss Cargo opening up ownership to private investors.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, in comparable cases in other industries\u0026mdash;such as express logistics, freight forwarding, telecommunications, airlines, and energy\u0026mdash;there has been a rise in trans-national companies with an international footprint that outweighs their incumbent markets by far. This phenomenon is often driven by large cross-border M\u0026amp;A activity. Successful companies in these industries have significantly revisited their commercial models, improved customer experience across process steps, introduced flexible offerings, enhanced quality of service, and offered better pricing structures. Freight rail would also benefit from thinking through its marketing and customer relationship models, which have not seen significant changes over the past 50 years. In this context, rail operators could explore four options for developing new market share:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cul\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eImprove cost efficiencies\u003c/em\u003e by using all possibilities to improve economies of scale, scope, and skills. For example, rail operators could create truly seamless networks across the EU; develop new operating models to cover the first and last mile; consider partnerships with other rail operators or new actors; and leverage new technologies such as automatic coupling to optimize operations, automatic processing to simplify back-office processes, and advanced analytics to optimize network planning and train scheduling.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOffer world-class service\u003c/em\u003e by applying the latest technologies to enhance processes from customer generation through to pricing and after sales service. For example, rail operators could implement easy web-based booking solutions for end-to-end logistics across operators and infrastructure managers; apply advanced pricing approaches to attract volume; and optimize margins.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDevelop competitive insights\u003c/em\u003e by understanding the competition\u0026rsquo;s value add for clients and their pricing approach. For example, rail operators could develop a clean sheeting tool for competitive modes, develop new tools to predict needs, and design select pricing points to offer a better value proposition to clients.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eProactively look for new clients\u003c/em\u003e by developing new offerings to attract new types of goods to rail; and potentially developing partnership with companies willing to lower their carbon emissions and create a more sustainable operation strategy.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eDoubling freight rail\u0026rsquo;s modal share represents a significant challenge. It requires real will, strong choices, and an active involvement of all stakeholders, including states, regulators, operators, infrastructure managers, and industries.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003eInvesting in technology, and modernizing the network, will be critical\u0026mdash;but this is only part of what is needed to truly transform the industry. Regulators could also provide support, particularly in revising the competitive and financial model. And operators would benefit from rethinking their business models and coming up with innovative ways to attract new clients and deliver value.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2022-01-21T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eJose Vassallo and Mark Fagan, \u003cem\u003eNature or nurture: Why do railroads carry greater freight share in the United States than in Europe?\u003c/em\u003e, Taubman Center research working paper series, number WP05-15, December 20, 2005; current on your favorite topics"}}}]},"articlesidebar":{"results":[{"mediaID":{"value":"1"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eEnabling seamless movement across borders.\u003c/em\u003e There is a standard gauge connection to Barcelona, and beyond, through a new high-speed line; similar capacity could be added at border crossings such as Port Bou and Cerbere.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eIncreasing corridor capacity.\u003c/em\u003e Connecting corridors, especially along the Mediterranean coast in France and Spain, need increased capacity to handle larger flows. Part of the solution could include adding European Train Control System (ETCS) equipment and removing level crossings.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eGiving customers access points.\u003c/em\u003e Standard gauge connections in Spain could be expanded so that key areas of origin, such as Almeria, have direct access to the standard gauge network. In addition, infrastructure investments need to incorporate high-capacity terminals which can handle 740m trains efficiently.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eOffering attractive supply-chain solutions.\u003c/em\u003e Appropriate supply-chain solutions\u0026mdash;with clear benefits over road transport in terms of cost, reliability, and speed\u0026mdash;could attract key industries. For instance, as a significant portion of traffic is made up of perishable agricultural products, rail will need to compete with door-to-door truck services that provide fresh food to customers. Solutions could include cold-chain services based on reefer containers, average train speeds of more than 80km per hour between terminals, and reliable schedules.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e"}},"aboutTheAuthors":{"jsonValue":{"value":""}},"headline":{"jsonValue":{"value":"The following strategic interventions could help to win traffic back for rail"}},"footnotes":{"value":""},"showShareTools":{"boolValue":true},"backgroundColor":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Lightest Grey"},"value":{"value":"lightest-grey"}}},"gradientDirection":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Bottom Right"},"value":{"value":"bottom-right"}}},"renderMode":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"Collapsible"},"value":{"value":"default"}}},"isAboutAuthor":{"boolValue":false},"background":{"targetItem":null},"image":{"src":null,"alt":""}},{"mediaID":{"value":"2"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"\u003cp\u003eFour success factors seem to have helped the port to make rail attractive and increase modal share:\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eOpening up access to rail infrastructure.\u003c/em\u003e Opening tracks within the port to all railway operators increased shippers\u0026rsquo; willingness to move goods on rail as they could tailor their solutions with preferred partners. Service quality\u0026mdash;for example, the frequency of train services\u0026mdash;increased significantly. There are now 57 different rail transport companies using the port\u0026rsquo;s infrastructure, with 1,300 trains per week going in and out of the port.[[footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eReducing infrastructure bottlenecks.\u003c/em\u003e The port improved both infrastructure and operations to speed up and increase capacity on rail services. It removed infrastructural bottlenecks, for instance by completing the Kattwyk railway bridge in 2020. This is one of the largest lifting bridges in the world, with a middle section that can be raised to allow ships to pass underneath. Dedicated to rail traffic, the bridge has increased capacity for rail services.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eCooperating closely in operations.\u003c/em\u003e The Hamburg port provides shunting services as well as joint traffic management with other companies, leading to increased operational efficiency.\u003c/p\u003e\n\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eConnecting the hinterland.\u003c/em\u003e Building rail infrastructure in the rest of the country was just as important as increasing infrastructure at the port, so the system could handle larger numbers of trains. Segments with third tracks and sidings have been added to handle 740m trains\u0026mdash;and new freight arteries are planned for the
